abstract: Google’s agreement with some news publishers over its new Fast Flip service resembles other deals that Google has cut with content owners.
snippet: Google’s agreement with some news publishers over its new Fast Flip service resembles other deals that Google has cut with content owners.
lead_paragraph: The years-long tug of of war between publishers and Google has become familiar. Publishers complain that Google makes money off their backs and want to be paid for their content. Google replies that what it does — indexing the Web, offering search tools that allow people to find content — is not only perfectly legal, but also benefits publishers.

headline.main: Google’s Fast Flip Deal Has a Familiar Ring

abstract: A not-so quick survey of Google’s new Fast Flip.
snippet: A not-so quick survey of Google’s new Fast Flip.
lead_paragraph: The functional elegance of RSS feeds that bring news to your door like a faithful dog is beyond dispute, but no one is going to argue that it’s fun to look at or replicates the offline thrill of flipping a page and finding something completely unexpected. But online reading might have just picked up a few tricks from the offline world. As Miguel Helft has noted, Google made of a bit of a splash on Monday at the TechCrunch50 conference when they unveiled Fast Flip, an experimental news hub that uses pre-loaded static images of news pages so that readers can quickly scan through an a visually inviting database of news.

headline.main: A Not-So-Fast Flip Through Google’s Shiny New Toy
